channel.title: Home on Luke Jaeger
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Luke Jaeger

item.title: Fish With Unique IDs
item.description: I listen better when I’m drawing. This one was drawn during the artists panel before the opening of the Parallel Play group exhibition, where I have a couple of pieces.

item.title: Got The Radio On
item.description: At the Parallel Play artists panel, Julia Jacquette talked about needing the radio on in the studio. That filtered into what I was drawing at the time. I listen better when I’m drawing (yes I heard what you said, believe me!) and also tend to work with music playing.

item.title: ORD Airport People
item.description: What else can you do with a 2 hour layover in Chicago but try to draw everyone who walks by? You get a few seconds per person, not enough time to screw it up!

item.title: Dream (The Frogulator)
item.description: Another one of those dream images that pop up fully formed and without any context: just a sharp-dressed frog rolling through the desert in a big old American car.

item.title: Dream | Bimble Bamble Bitches (Text Only Version)
item.description:
Elaboration of the rap lyric I dreamed a couple of months ago. I used vinyl-cut type as a mask, and learned a couple of things about which acrylic mediums to use around mask elements (in short: Matte medium works great ; don’t introduce GAC-500 until after you peel the mask away).

Halfway through, I realized I had unconsciously cribbed the design from “More More More Said The Baby.” A belated tip of the hat to Vera B. Williams for her unerring layout and color chops.

item.title: Elkmobile (For Amara)
item.description: My daughter texted me indignantly because the New York Times Spelling Bee puzzle wouldn’t accept “Elkmobile.” This drawing is by her request.

item.title: How To Ask If The Convenience Store Sells Hard-Boiled Eggs When None Of The Staff Speak English Or Spanish
Runaway Patient At Mass General
item.description:
As we approached the hospital on a cold Boston morning, this rail-thin young woman wearing only hospital pants and a tank top came sprinting out into traffic, pursued by hospital security guards. They caught up to her before she could get hurt and gently bundled her into a wheelchair.

I’m always impressed by the efficiency, kindness and compassion of the Mass General staff, and these guys were no exception. Whoever that patient is, I wish her good health.

item.title: All The Round Things
item.description: It’s Higgins Black Magic plus alcohol, in case you’re wondering.

item.title: Dream | Bimble Bamble Bitches (Billy Joel Surgically Disassembled)
item.description: Though he’s not in my usual dream lineup, my students had a Billy Joel playlist on the other day and he lodged in my brain. However, I’m much more interested in the “Bimble Bamble Bitchs” rap. If anyone cares to record it, I’m all ears.

item.title: A Method For Counting The Days
Bismuth Crystal
item.description: I’ve been learning how to make these extraordinary crystals. Here’s one I particularly like!

item.title: Skeleton Crew At The Hospital (For Lisa)
2nd Street And Gowanus Canal Looking West, View 1
2nd Street And Gowanus Canal Looking West, View 2
2nd Street And Gowanus Canal Looking West, View 3
Turn Off Your Brain (Sketch)
item.description: Recently discovered in a drawer of a desk that I haven’t used in a long time.

item.title: 3 Dogs (If Then Else)
item.description: More fun with anamorphic cubes! These are mounted on ready-made hexagonal painting panels with custom-built beveled enclosures, creating the illusion of a 3D cube. You can assemble these three little scenes into any number of narratives; pick one that floats your boat.

item.title: Dream | A Train Full Of Paper
Breakfast In Budapest
item.description: Software and spraypaint! I laser cut CMYK halftones out of oilboard to make stencils, then “printed” them with spraypaint. It worked! I especially like the oranges.

item.title: Underground Creatures
item.description: Drawn during a very lovely Pioneer Valley Jazz Shares concert at Wistariahurst.

item.title: Cliff Street Substation
item.description: I’m a sucker for this 1930’s architectural typography. The Cliff Street Substation powers the IND subway (that’s the A train to you). Here’s what was on the site before they built it.

item.title: Fulton Street Subway Entrance Detail
item.description: Beauty and rapture. Bury me, I am dead.

item.title: Court St / Clark St Elevator Men Of the 1970s
item.description: Hard to believe our parents let us ride unaccompanied in elevators operated by these guys.

item.title: Hot Soaks For Wart Treatment
item.description: One of my kids came back from the dermatologist’s office where they were amused by the pamphlets with details about every possible skin condition. The title of one pamphlet became the prompt for this drawing.

item.title: New Yorker Hotel
item.description:
Yes it’s the same New Yorker Hotel featured in this incredibly bizarre news story, where 21-year-old Peggy Lee sang with Benny Goodman’s band, and where Nikola Tesla lived on the 33rd floor for 12 years.

Although the Unification Church no longer uses the hotel as an industrial-scale dorm for thousands of Moonies, apparently they do still own the building.

item.title: Varick & Houston, Looking Southwest
item.description:
My nephew put me onto this funky film stock so I bought some to celebrate the 50th birthday of my Nikkormat FT2. (The lens is a little sticky, but other than that the camera is basically good as new. Can you imagine any digital camera lasting half that long?). After stewing in the digital swamp for so long, shooting film felt like a clean breeze – yes, I still did the montage & color tweaks in Photoshop.

Anyway, I’m pretty sure I shot this same photomontage on the same corner with the same camera in 1995, while I was wandering around a very different New York shooting images for what eventually became 5 DREAMS. There’s something pleasing about the proportions of that building. I’ll post the old shots if I ever find them – I really ought to digitize those images, some of them are probably pretty good!

item.title: Dream | Zooming Down The Highway On A Mattress
item.description: This is one of my go-to recurring dreams. It was in very heavy rotation a few years ago; now it only pops up once in a while. O who can fathom the ways of the brain?

item.title: London Underground Northern Line, Time Exposure
Tallis Street, London
item.description: The way this building’s curvy masonry and vintage hoisting boom are both functional and ornamental really hit all my spots. The fact that it’s located on Tallis Street is icing on the cake.

item.title: Bus With Tank Treads, Lobster Claws, And Human Ass
Dream | I'll Never Get There In Time
Dream | Burying The Cables
item.description: There was more to it, but this was the basic mood.

item.title: Dream | Here's What You Have To Understand About Dave Edmunds
item.description: Yes I came of age in the 1980s, so of course I have a soft spot for Dave Edmunds. These days he rarely crosses my mind, and I’m not sure why he popped up here. Weirdly, right after sketching this dream I heard on the radio that it was Edmunds’ 80th birthday.

item.title: Mexico City
item.description: Drawn in Parque Mexico, CDMX, while the lovely Shoshana read “You Dreamed Of Empires” out loud

item.title: Frog Train With Brain And Bees
Dream | Leonard Nimoy In 1975 Wearing A Trench Coat Festooned With Acorns
Tube Cathedral 2
item.description: Another anamorphic construction, designed in OnShape CAD.

item.title: To Get To The Other Side
Through The Window
item.description: You used to be able to look out the window of the Manhattan-bound D train as it crossed the bridge and see directly into a whole bunch of Chinatown sweatshops. Immigrant women sitting shoulder-to-shoulder behind rows of sewing machines. I believe it ran 24/7. Today this spot is probably 10 miles from the nearest factory.

item.title: Space Local
item.description: This is a local train making express stops only.

item.title: Post-Industrial Plein Air | Northampton Bike Path Underpass | 42.329047, -72.632236, Looking East
Plein Air Under The Manhattan Bridge | 40.709532, -73.991815, Looking South
If | Then | Else
item.description: I was plein air painting and had a bunch of paint left on the palette. Did you expect me to just throw it away?

item.title: Everybody I Ever Worked With From 1980 To 1993 Or So, Drawn From Memory
item.description:
In my teenage years and 20’s, I had a ton of jobs: office-assistant-gopher at a travel bureau and an ad agency; various quick-print and xerox shops; a whole bunch of offset lithography and pre-press shops; a couple of scenic construction companies and several animation studios; plus some others I’m probably forgetting.

Whenever I left one of these jobs, I’d draw the faces of my co-workers from memory.

I can remember stories and details about some of these folks; others are completely missing from my memory.

If you recognize yourself, let me know!

item.title: Dream | Will You Just Look At These Fucking Ricardos
Dream | The Famous Subway Over The Sea
Dream | Larry King Officiates A Wedding In The City Of Giant Pipes
Shosh Reading 'Maus' With Trixie
item.description: “Why am I reading this book again? Am I nuts?”

item.title: Note To Self (Turn Off Your Brain)
Incident Report
item.description: Dude falsely accused me of bumping into his car at the dog path parking lot. He insisted on filing an incident report, so I had to as well. Presumably his claim was rejected and I gave some bored bureaucrat a laugh.

item.title: Dream | Putting Lipstick On A Train
Dream | Alone On A Deserted Road Late One Night In 1946, Fred Fniffke Experienced A Career-Changing Event
Recursive Pipe Painting 1
item.description: Started making paintings on paper of these giant pipes waiting to be buried. It wasn’t that interesting, but then I thought of making paintings of the pipes on the pipes. No audience except maybe a few construction workers, and whoever digs up the pipes in some future century.

item.title: Recursive Pipe Painting 2
item.description: Started making paintings on paper of these giant pipes waiting to be buried. It wasn’t that interesting, but then I thought of making paintings of the pipes on the pipes. No audience except maybe a few construction workers, and whoever digs up the pipes in some future century.

item.title: Zoom Meeting Notes
item.description: I like to draw during meetings. In fact I kind of have to. Otherwise I’m sure to say something totally inappropriate.

item.title: Will Ya Look At That Poor Hobo Out There
item.description: Reading this article after the events of 1/6/2021 reminded me of this cartoon I dashed off in 2018, around the time of the “Steve Bannon getting invited and then disinvited from the New Yorker Festival” kerfuffle.

item.title: Post-Industrial Plein Air | Excavator, 42.327666, -72.632737, Looking West
One Alcohol-Soaked Evening In London
item.description: This too really happened. For egregious behavior and public drunkenness, the Brits are unmatched.

item.title: Extended Family | James Jamerson At Home
item.description: When I was 9 or 10, my mom took me to a survey of anamorphic art at the Brooklyn Museum. This exhibition spanned continents and centuries (from Holbein’s The Ambassadors to contemporary works) and it’s no exaggeration to say it blew my young mind permanently. Anamorphic and forced-perspective miniature environments have fascinated me ever since. Lately I’ve been designing and constructing them using CAD software, 3D printing, and laser cutting technologies.

item.title: Dream | Unauthorized Exhibition Of My Scrap Paper
Death Rides For Free
item.description: Made during a lovely afternoon workshop at Oaxaca’s radical printmaking collective Subterraneos

item.title: Dream | Funny Money
item.description: Racist neighbors, secrets of the comedy biz, plus the “windshield wiper dance”

item.title: Fimbel Lab Anamorphic Logo
item.description: This was one of my first attempts to build an anamorphic object using CAD software. Come by the Mount Holyoke Makerspace some time and see it! My colleagues Kris Camp and Shani Mensing were instrumental in fabricating this thing. The original logo was designed by Joyce He.

item.title: Post-Industrial Plein Air | Oxbow Rail Bridge
Post-Industrial Plein Air | Oil Storage Tanks

Post-Industrial Plein Air | Ferry Street Mills, Easthampton Mass

Post-Industrial Plein Air | Behind Local Burgy, Williamsburg Mass
Post-Industrial Plein Air | Behind Baystate Medical, Northampton Mass
Memory Is The Best Reminder
item.description:
Among my many bizarre jobs, one of the most bizarre was a seriously down-on-its-luck scenery shop in Oakland. It was perhaps the greatest concentration of fire code violations ever assembled in a single building, which is a whole story of its own.

What’s relevant here is that the owner had launched a promotional campaign with the tagline “Memory is the best reminder.” The more you think about it, the more meaningless it gets – it’s actually kind of brilliant in a way.

item.title: Emergency Masks
item.description: I am in awe of people who can crank out topical political cartoons on deadline. I did manage a few during those terrible years between 2016 and 2021. This one kind of drew itself.

item.title: Dream | A Gallon Of Glue
item.description: This was the whole dream. No further information available!

item.title: Amara & Koko Knitting, Feat Sasha
item.description: The pandemic was stressful and bizarre, but it did have its moments of coziness. I don’t think we’re anywhere close to done processing the whole thing.

item.title: Lets Learn Yiddish
item.description: The closest I ever got to internet fame was this image. Its brief moment of virality peaked when Bette Middler retweeted it. I’m just proud of how putting the insults in alphabetical order landed the four lumpen offspring neatly in a row.

item.title: Take Off Your Skin (Island)
item.description: Animation background art from Take Off Your Skin

item.title: Uninvited Thoughts
item.description: I’m not making this up.

item.title: Text Satan!
item.description: Some co-workers and I stopped into this beaten-down Italian pastry shop in New Haven one evening. It was raining buckets and the place was about to close. The girl behind the counter kept yelling into her phone (it was a little hard to tell when she was talking to us and when she wasn’t) and the screen was smashed, so she could only use the phone by voice commands. She explained that she was trying to text her boyfriend, who was listed in her contacts as ‘Satan’.

item.title: Picking Up Printing Supplies Of Questionable Provenance In Abandoned Court Street Office Building, ca. 1980
item.description: I had an after-school job at a quick-print shop in Brooklyn Heights. My job duties included picking up batches of stolen printing supplies from the drop point, an abandoned upper floor of a sketchy Court St office building. Sometimes I went in the company of my counterpart, a black kid who worked for the Xerox place down the street, with whose Hasidic owners my boss, a hard-drinking Italian named Frank, had a prickly competitive / collaborative relationship. “Hey kid, go down to the jews and borrow a case of paper.”

item.title: Dream | Rosh Hashana & Prednisone
item.description: Not advocating that anyone abuse steroids, but I have never been more productive than during a course of Prednisone. Talk to your doctor!

item.title: Dream | Robot In Elevator
item.description: I was in charge of transporting a fancy sex robot from Manhattan to Brooklyn, a difficult journey by train, bicycle and shopping cart, made more difficult by the robot’s habit of spouting random facts whenever there was an awkward lull in conversation. This was supposed to be some kind of machine-learning algorithm for ‘small talk’, but it didn’t work so well.

item.title: Dream | Fair Weather Friends Of The JFK Library
item.description: This is an oldie that I re-scanned and colored in Photoshop. One blustery day in the early 80s, Shoshana & I were walking around Columbia Point car-less and broke when we wandered into the newly opened JFK Library. The place was staffed by women who had clearly been avid JFK supporters in 1960 – they were all wearing their vintage campaign buttons and talking about JFK like they were expecting him to show up any minute – and a weird mood prevailed. We realized that it was November 22, the anniversary of JFK’s assassination.

item.title: Run Away From The Big Potato! (After Jack Kirby)
New And Noteworthy
item.description: Let’s hope I don’t have to use this one again.

item.title: Motorman, WTF?
item.description: This really happened.

item.title: Mark Lepore, Drawn From Memory
item.description:
Mark Lepore was my graduate advisor and mentor at Mass Art.

The first day of my second year of grad school was 9/11.

I got caught in traffic and arrived late for Mark’s graduate seminar. As the only one who knew what was going on outside the dark, soundproof room where the class met, it fell to me to tell Mark and the other grad students what I’d been hearing on the radio on the way in. Mark, an ex-New Yorker like me, freaked out and we all ran down the hall to a tiny office where a janitor was watching the news on a beaten-down black & white TV. We arrived just in time to see the second tower collapse.

Mark took his own life on Sept 11, 2005. I think of him often but especially on that date.

Sedlec Ossuary, Kutna Hora, Czech Republic
item.description: This ossuary contains the bones of somewhere between 40,000 and 70,000 people. It is perhaps the most metal tourist attraction anywhere. In fact, while we were there, a traveling metal band pulled up in their tour bus for a visit!

item.title: Pfaueninsel Palace, Berlin
item.description: Frederick Wilhelm II had this faux-ruined architectural folly constructed on Berlin’s Peacock Island. It’s quite silly.

item.title: An Agent Will Inform You When Your Mask Is No Longer Necessary
You Do The Monkey, The Mashed Potatoes
With Koko At Haight Ashbury Music Store, 8/19/1996
I Don't Think So
item.description: During an episode of depression, I passed by a storefront selling lots of uplifting word-art. The cumulative effect of all those affirmations made me feel worse. Naturally I wondered if making negative, bummer word art would have the opposite effect and cheer me up. It actually kind of worked.

item.title: Dad Paying Bills Late At Night
Chicken Rescue
item.description: As a child, I thought the Seal of the City Of New York (as seen on every police car) depicted a policeman and a fireman rescuing a chicken on a life net.

item.title: Dream | A Bike Inside A Freight Train
Extended Family | Josephine Baker At IRT Substation 44, Bronx, 1927
Dream | Tap Dancer In Power Plant
item.description:
This enigmatic, top-hatted character appeared in a dream, performing a very solemn and dignified sort of dance. In dress and bearing he resembled some old-time hoofer like Bojangles Robinson or Sandman Sims, though it wasn’t exactly a tap dance, more a soft shoe / buck dance type of thing – anyway, it was a compelling and emotionally charged image which evoked something of my childhood immersion in old movies and my parents’ 78 records. A few years later he ended up as a character in my animated film Fishwife.

For the Fishwife dance animation, I rotoscoped video of a contemporary buck dancer whose motion had the right vibe. His name escapes me, but I do remember that tracking him down to get permission was no small feat. He was a bit confused by my asking to use his roto’d likeness in the film, and he didn’t want his name in the credits. Happily he did say yes to the whole thing.

item.title: Fish And Skulls Under Old Washington Street El, Boston, 1985
item.description:
Good old Harry The Greek’s, where I got my first pair of safety shoes.

In the background: Dudley Station on the old Orange Line elevated line. The platforms were made of wood, and a “Let’s Make Every Day Safe Driving Day” billboard, featuring a likeness of Eisenhower, remained remarkably intact 30+ years on, probably because its location directly over the tracks made it vandal-proof.

The photo was taken during a big sewer main upgrade project which turned loose an unbelievable number of rats.

item.title: Busiest People Ever: At The Airport
If You Leave Me, I'll Go Crazy
Dream | A 50 Pound Bag Of Photoshop
item.description: and yes, I did make the image in photoshop

item.title: Help Me Rid My House Of Richard Nixon
La Mono Nagra: An Analog Tale (Massachusetts Review, Vol 52 issue 1)
Texas, 2007
item.description: A sketch made during a 2007 trip to Huntsville, TX for a family wedding. Huntsville is home to a huge prison where the majority of America’s executions are carried out. A visit to the Texas Prison Museum, the death of KC & The Sunshine Band guitarist Jerome Smith in a bulldozer accident, and a general background note of Bush-era paranoia all contribute to the imagery.

item.title: When Me Body Lay Down In The Grave (4 Vignettes)
item.description: Production still from When Me Body Lay Down In The Grave

item.title: A Ride To Work
item.description: A reasonably accurate reconstruction of a real conversation with Corey Smithson

item.title: 1978 (Ladies & Gentlemen, The Rolling Stones) (Massachusetts Review, Vol 46 issue 1)
These Are A Few Of My Favorite Smells
The Thing Wraps Tefillin In Subway
item.description: When I made this painting in 2001, excitement was in the air (much of it generated by Michael Chabon’s The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay) about what had been the secret history of Jews in the “Golden Age” of comics. Imagine my delight a year later when Marvel put The Thing in an explicitly Jewish storyline.

item.title: Mister Zip Lost Under Brooklyn Bridge
item.description:
Mister Zip was the discontinued cartoon mascot of the US Postal Service. A relic of the campaign to encourage the use of ZIP codes (introduced in 1963), images of Mister Zip were still visible in post offices when I was a kid. His lumpen body and rubber-hose limbs were completely without refinement, not at all like the highly abstracted, geometric style of other 1960’s & 70’s cartoons. He seemed perpetually victimized by his surroundings, hardly a desirable trait in a mailman. I found his pathetic and primitive quality compelling, and it made me want to place him in surreal and metaphorical situations.

This painting mattered to me because I started out trying to paint the underside of the Brooklyn Bridge from a photo, but got discouraged because of my sloppy brushwork. “It looks like a mess of goddam chicken bones,” I remember thinking — and then the lightbulb lit up! Bones = structural steelwork.

item.title: Dream | Late Model Cars Being Swept Into The Sea

I'm Just A Blackboard Eraser
item.description: An oldie, newly re-framed. “I’m just a blackboard eraser, hanging on the vine / Whistling for that schoolgirl who was once my valentine”

item.title: Greg & Harvey At Work
item.description:
A representation of one memorable day at the printing shop I worked at in SFO. Harvey was my boss and Greg was one of the pressmen. Greg was also a member of the Oakland Hell’s Angels (in fact he’d left his home in the Midwest to ride with them, his local Angels chapter being insufficiently badass, I guess). Wherever Greg went, bizarre stuff happened: on this particular day, Greg popped his head into our room after having gotten into a knife fight at the deli across the street, blood cascading from his face. We called an ambulance (against Greg’s protestations) and Harvey buried his face in his hands, trying to unsee the whole scene.

In the deep background, a running figure is pursued by a guy wielding an axe. This also really happened, though on a different day.

item.title: Dream Of Sarge
item.description: Assembled one day in the late 1980’s while under the heavy influence of Jess Collins

item.title: Dream Of Blondie And The Blind Actors
